text:
SPEAKER: Sandra is a
member of the Navajo Nation and has worked as an
engineer at Sandia National

Laboratories for 30 years. She earned her MS from
Stanford University

in structural engineering
and is the recipient of the 2021 Women in Technology
Award from the NM Technology

Council. Sandra's unique work focused on
providing technical assistance to US tribes, and she has
mentored 44 technical American

Indian and Alaska
Native college students. Sandra, so excited
to get started.

And take it away. SANDRA BEGAY: Thank you. And welcome to everybody
who's joined us,

whatever time zone you're on. For me, I'm coming on this
platform from Albuquerque, New

Mexico. As a member of
the Navajo Nation, I wanted to talk a little
bit more about my background.

With Navajo traditions
and Navajo Nation is the largest tribe
in the United States.

It covers three states,
the Arizona, New Mexico, a little bit of Utah area.

It's one of the largest
land-based tribes. It's also very large in
number, around 350,000

to 400,000 members of my tribe. But what I was
taught by my dad, who

is a tribal leader
is that when you're asked to talk in a public
forum such as this, you need to talk a little bit
more about your credentials,

because on Navajo Nation, we
don't just let anybody get up and talk to an audience
in a public fashion.

You have to explain a little
bit more about yourself. So I did get a
Bachelor of Science

from the University of New
Mexico, a master's degree in structural
engineering from Stanford

and, as been talked about,
I've been an engineer for quite a long time, 33 years
actually, 30 years

at the current job that I have. You'll hear from what
I'm going to tell you is that I just enjoy my career.

I've had very good workings
and wonderful managers,

great people to work with. But every story is not
always so rosy as it appears.

But I wanted to at least
describe to you that at-- raised by a
matriarch, my mom--

Navajo Nation, we are
all about the women. The women lead the clans.

All our inheritance
is from our mother. I'm born of the Naaneesht'ézhi
táchii'nii clan,

the Zuni clan of the Navajo. And I was born as a gift to my
dad's clan, the Bitter Water

people. I was raised on
the Navajo Nation, close-- very, very close. It's called a border town,
a border to the Navajo tribe

itself. But every weekend, my
dad was an official. So I would be on tribal
lands every Sunday.

He had community meetings
that he would attend to. And I was outside as a
young girl, running around.

And I think what I take
from that experience is to really appreciate the
natural beauty of where I was

raised, the beautiful Red
Rock canyons of the Gallup, New Mexico, area.

My home community's
called Church Rock. And there's actually a rock,
because in the Southwest

we have many rock formations. And that rock formation looks
a little bit like a church.

And I think being
descriptive of where I'm from may be helpful
to you, because we're very interested,
as tribal people,

acknowledging our culture. But we very much acknowledge
the places that we are from.

Some babies, when they're born,
you take the umbilical cord, and you bury that at
your home, on the land,

on the tribal lands,
on the reservation. And so for my dad, he
illustrated that as,

although as a leader who
lived in a border town, his umbilical cord,
his heart, his mind,

was attached to the
Church Rock area. And he actually had to take
his case to the Supreme

Court on Navajo Nation. And so that's how
I explain that it's so important to know where
I'm from, the conditions

that I grew up with. My dad, being a
tribal leader, he instilled in me being a leader
at every chance I could.

Even though I didn't have to
step up and lead anything, I was always taught to listen.

A leader always listens. From my mom-- she was
a public health nurse for the Indian Health
Service, all of her career.

And from her I learned to
break different barriers. And so today I wanted to talk
more about the philosophy

that I was taught
as a young girl and as a young woman about the
Navajo philosophy of walking

in beauty. So it's not just one aspect of
physically walking and feeling

like you're beautiful. That's too simplistic. It's your mind, your thoughts,
you're being, and all of you

takes on that notion of
doing things in a good way, in a positive way.

So when you walk
in beauty, you're trying to leave a
place maybe even more beautiful than it was,
through your speech,

through your actions. And you have to be able to do
that in different circumstance.

And so today, trying to
explain this walking and beauty path that I've been on has
been great and wonderful.

But there have been
some stumbling blocks. So I'll focus a little
bit of my talk on that.

And you can ask me any questions
about something that you hear. For my tribe and being a
matriarch and a Navajo,

I had to learn that, when
I went into engineering, I was into a patrilineal
world, male-dominated world.

And I had to shift
my thoughts into how I fit into that situation.

And it still has not changed. We don't have as many female
leaders as we could and should.

So in another sense, because
I have different duties, beyond a researcher,
beyond my work, I am a--

the University of New Mexico. So I am one of the
seven trustees, or regents, that sets the policy
and performance and hiring

and firing of the president of
the University of New Mexico. And so that is another
layer of leadership

that I've been able
to attain because of my good work and
recommendations from others

to the governor. And being recognized
that and approved by our legislative body, the
governing body of New Mexico,

is also another point
that I wanted to make is that, as you try to
do things in your career,

hopefully you will be
recognized for that. And then these opportunities
will start to open for you.

But I will say that,
as you understand where you want to be in life.

You also have to think,
how do you impact what you're responsible for?

So in my job, as I
was a project engineer for a long time, all internal
customers to the laboratory

I work for. Civil engineers, we talk
about the infrastructure. We talk about the customer.

We talk about
listening, and how much is it going to cost, when
is it going to be done. All of that great career
led to many opportunities

at my workplace which
culminated to working in strategic planning with the
president, laboratory director,

of where I work. And that's where I
learned that leaders get just as nervous
as an everyday person,

because we are people. If anything, you've
got to remember that. You may have a
position to be a leader

or something in
management as a director or as first-line manager.

But yet we are people,
and we do get nervous when there's a lot
of important meetings

that you're attending
or presenting. So that was eye-opening for
me that, as a staff member--

and I called myself a go-fer,
because I would go for this and go for that. As a staff member,
I didn't mind,

because I was learning and
observing and being comfortable with who I am to be able to
work with top-notch leaders

and be confident in my
work to support them. But as a leader
myself, I'm also very

aware that I'm being watched. And I don't mean
that in a bad way, but being observed, because
another unique piece

to my career is, if you
take the US workforce that are engineers that are
born in the United States,

I, as a Native woman engineer,
am one out of 13,000. So my alma mater, the
University of New Mexico,

has a basketball arena
that the lower level seats about 13,000 people.

So that's something
I can visualize. If you put 13,000 US
engineers in that arena,

I would be the only woman
who's a Native American. So some people call
that a double-minority.

You're in a double bind as
far as representing yourself in the workplace.

And so I keep that
number in my head, because when I feel like
I'm isolated, or I'm alone,

or I don't see people
like me in what I do, it's because there aren't any. And I have to admit that.

It's a very unique circumstance. And early in my career,
I was a little bit

uncomfortable with that. And like I said, the word
"isolated" came to mind.

But I had to learn how to adapt. How do you feel comfortable
when you are the only one?

And that's part of where I hope
you learned something from me today is that, instead of
seeing that as a negative,

I turn that, in that Navajo
philosophy, to be something I'm very proud of.

And I think the
other piece to that is that it lends my
abilities, my experience,

my qualifications to be in
very unique circumstance. So the work that
I do today working

with tribes across the United
States, it's very much a niche. I actually created
the job for myself.

I started out 20 years ago with
a little bit of seed money, and I proved to the sponsor
from the federal government

that I was capable and
able to do the job, and I could relate to tribal
members on the tribal lands

to help them with
renewable energy projects. So technical
assistance to the tribe was the base of
where I got my start.

So over time, it became
a full-time position. And over time, I added more and
more funding by adding interns.

The reason I chose
to have interns-- and right now I'm going to be
close to the 50-person mark

of interns that
I'm working with, because I've got two
year-round interns today, and I'm hiring three
summer interns for in May

will get started full time. So it's really close to
50 interns over 20 years.

I'm very proud of
the fact that instead of feeling isolated and
alone and a low budget,

I understood that I could hire
interns very lower cost, easily

done. I had 90 days to try
to work with a student. Now, one of the things that I
did recognize is the students

are related to the science,
technology, engineering math fields. They're very selective in
what they've chosen to study.

And some people have
said that I cherry-pick. And you can say that. But I'm trying to get the
Native American students who

are in the STEM fields to
work with me for 90 days. And in that sense,
I wasn't by myself.

I built my own team. And over these years, I've been
able to follow their careers.

And I am so very proud
of the different interns that I've had, including Nora
Cata, who's online today.

And I thank her
profusely for having me get to know that the
people who put on this forum

to be able to talk to you today. I will acknowledge that,
because of what I do today,

about a year ago,
I've been invited to be a part of the Women's
Committee at the National

Academy. And so this is the US National
Academy of Science, Engineers,

and Medicine. And there's a Women's
Committee that covers all of those
National Academies focused

in on different areas. And there, I'm just
amazed at the women

that are on this committee. They're such at a key
point in their career.

Many have been the only one
in their fields of study for a long time. And they've become leaders
in different fashion--

maybe not a management
leader, but a thought leader, an action leader by
all that they've done.

And so being a
part of that group is a very key honor, in my mind. But one thing we
talked about is topics

that we could cover
in this next year. And the way I
described it is I would

like women who are at the higher
ranks to tell their stories.

That comes back to
my Navajo traditions of how do I tell you about
what I've done in my career.

Rather than a
PowerPoint presentation, I'd rather just be here
today and tell you my story

and tell you in a way
that hopefully you can relate to and ask
more questions of me.

So what I've described
to the committee is, I want people to
tell their story.

For Native Americans,
that's a way to communicate that they're
very comfortable with. And what's interesting is
it's not a part of the way

that science, math, engineering,
technology, medicine is used to sharing information.

Even the word "sharing"
can be a very generic way

that women use. And I'm a woman so I'm going
to use that word "sharing." That's how I convey
information is by sharing--

that we get used to
the language that we talk about amongst each
other, that we don't have to be in our
patrilineal workplace

and communicate the
way it's expected. But we get to communicate
the way that we would like

and in the form and
fashion that we want. And so one of the ideas I've
been trying to get more people

to understand is that we've
talked a long time about glass ceilings, where you're only
able to rise up and get

through the ranks to a point
where you're acknowledged in your career for your work
by breaking that ceiling,

that you don't just
see what's above you. And it's clear. You can see it. But you can't get there because
that glass is in the way.

Well, I want to tell
you today that I've broken many glass ceilings. But yet what I did
not expect and what

I would love for
you to ask about is I'm actually finding shards
of glass that have come and cut

me. And this is not physically
cut, but mentally, emotionally,

dialogues-- that I
get into conversations that I don't expect some
negativity that I've received.

It's like-- so when
you break something, there's actually some byproduct,
which could be hurtful.

It could be toxic if you let it. And what I'd love
to just understand is that we, as women,
have a natural tendency

to be nurturing. I'm not going to
say all women are, but there's a natural tendency
to help, to assist, to help

grow, to lead. And I deliberate with
the word "nurture," that if I acknowledge
that something's

happening to me at that
nature of shards of glass that maybe you can relate
to what I'm saying.

I've had comments when I was
early in my career of, well, why do you get that assignment?

I'll give you an example. I was given an
assignment corporately, for the whole laboratory,
to study a child care

center for our laboratory for
all the new employees that were having children,
that maybe that would

help them to give some support
to them as far as a place to bring their children. And then it would be
right near work or right

near where they worked. And there were many women
that actually said to me, oh, Sandra, you got that
assignment because you're

I have this assignment. The reason I have
this assignment, because I asked for it. I want a benefit for
all people at the lab.

Maybe it's women
with young children. Maybe it's the men
who have new children. I want them to
have this resource.

And by the way, I do
not have children. I've decided in my career and
my life not to have children.

So having somebody turn
something that I thought was a beautiful and
interesting assignment

to making it like I did it
personally for my own gain is one of the shards of
glass that I have an example

to tell you. It's just not right. And at the time, I didn't I
didn't confront the person

with the way I felt. But as I thought about it--
and I'm very analytical-- I thought later, why did
that bother me so much?

And I had to really attribute
that to misunderstanding,

people aren't understanding
that I, as a project manager and as an engineer, take on
all kinds of assignments.

You can't always make it so
personal and internal to you as a personal gain.

That was never the case. I think the others with my
role as a regent or trustee

at the University of New
Mexico, we have public meetings every other month. And there was a point where we
had some public comment that

was, in my mind, a little too
derogatory of our president, who is the first president--
woman president that we've ever

had in our 100-plus-year
history of our institution. And I didn't appreciate
that they were commenting

on what kind of car she drove,
what kind of necklace she had, claiming that her
pearl necklace that she

was wearing that day was
like she was above everybody. She was touching her
pearls in a fashion

that she was just thinking about
the students and the faculty and staff as minions or peons.

And I think that's
the word they used. And I thought, that's not right. So when I had a chance
to comment back, I said,

do you know what? I wear a necklace usually. And if I was to
touch my necklace, it would not be saying I have
this, and you don't have that.

It's remember I was given this
gift by one of my relatives because she knows that
I do public speaking,

that I do presentations. And it reflects my native
culture very beautifully.

And that's the way I would
wear this necklace, not to say I have this and
you don't have that--

many crazy misunderstandings
that are subtle but very much unappreciated.

And I'll have to let you know
that you have to understand, any time you have
a confrontation,

when you have a
negative situation, you put your personal
energy into that.

And over time, I've learned I'm
not going to fight every fight. Maybe it's not even my fight.

And I have to think about it. Do I have the personal energy? Is this relationship
important to me?

Is this a random
colleague or this a stranger that has
said something to me? Is it worth my effort?

Is it worth something
for that people to learn about what they should
think differently, to not

misinterpret me and who I am? Or is it just let it go because
it's not that important?

And I've had to do
that many a times because I just don't want
to get into conversations

like that with everybody,
especially strangers. I'm not here to educate
someone who's misunderstanding.

But in a forum like this, I am
more than willing to do that, to help clarify who I am,
what I do, and why I do it.

And that that's
part of, I think, taking on that positivity
of walking in beauty in conversations that you have.

The other, I would say,
walking in beauty for me is giving good quality
to the work that I do.

Because I work with tribes
across the United States in various avenues, I am so
respectful of those leaders,

because many times they've
been in a position that been appointed, or
they've been elected.

But they choose to serve. And there's appreciation for me. And that experience is
probably from my father.

He was an elected
official, and he had to put up with
a lot of negativity. And so if I can be
a positive force

to help them solve
a community problem, I'm more than
willing to do that.

I think that's a part
of where I really love to understand what people
need as far as solutions.

I will have to say, there's
a balance you have to strike. So I left the lab for
about three years.

I intended not to go back. I had gotten my dream job. Or my dream at the time
was running a nonprofit

that helped me
grow as a student, as a Native American in
science and technology.

And this was the
American Indian Science and Engineering Society. The acronym is AISES.

You can look that
up on their website, and I'll put it in the
chat, if you'd like-- AISES.org.

But that's an organization
that I belong to. And what was so
unique about that and why I gave so much time and
effort is because they never

put anything in front of me
that was a block or a hindrance. There was no glass ceiling
in that organization for me.

I could go at the
top level of what I wanted to do to help
that organization.

And I thought about
it, and I wanted to be the executive leader
for that organization, called

the executive director. And I got the job. And I was the
national spokesperson. So I was speaking all the
time with corporations

about diversity, how
do you increase women in the workplace,
how do you support underrepresented minorities
in the United States.

I got to travel to New
Zealand and meet Maori folks-- just wonderful
opportunities for me

to grow and to grow as a person
and gain all different types of insights in
working with people

and very different cultures. Even though tribal communities
may seem homogeneous,

they're not. Every tribe has a very
different culture, and many have very
distinct languages

and distinct histories. So it was insightful
for me to be at the top job of what
I thought I could do

and the rest of my
career, retire from that. But lo and behold, I gave
everything to that job.

And I hate to say
this, but sometimes we as women give too
much to our jobs,

give too much to the work,
give of ourselves to a point that I wound up in
the emergency room.

I had given every ounce of
energy to that organization, and my body said, no.

I came down very ill, got hit
with all kinds of cold and flu
because my immunities were down. I gave everything to the job. And I'll give you one evidence.

Today, my complexion is a
lot lighter so I'm Navajo. I'm full-blooded Navajo.

But I was browner at
that time, because I became so anemic it took some
of the color out of my face.

And so it's interesting that,
over time, to reflect on that, is Sandra, you cannot
keep doing this,

because it could
harm your health. And look, this is what the
deities have shown you. You're going to be
a little bit lighter

in complexion because of all
that you gave at one point in time. And the lesson was learned.

Don't do that again. There's always a balance between
your work, your home life,

your relationships that you just
cannot let work have everything

of you. You've got to say no. And I've learned that over time. And you'll have to
learn to do that too.

The other is opportunities
will come to you as you gain experience, and you've
got good credentials,

and you've got a great,
incredible reputation. You'll be sought out. But you cannot take
every opportunity.

And you're going to
have to be a little more strategic in your thinking. So I'm going to leave
with a little bit of,

how do you do strategic
planning for yourself? I had a very wonderful mentor.
His name is Don Coyis, K-- excuse me, C-O-Y-I-S, Don.

He created a nonprofit
for Native American people to become sober.

As you might know-- now you will know-- there's a lot of alcoholism
and drug addiction

on our tribal lands because
of the lack of hope, the lack of opportunity. And many do not have the
education that I had,

I was able to obtain. And if you don't have education
to further your career

and further your life, sometimes
you're held back by that, and you have very dire
economic development and family

situations, and you don't have
as much hope as you might have if you've had opportunities.

And to understand from
Don and his philosophy, he taught me as a young
undergraduate student

that it's going to be hard. The STEM fields are hard. Being the only person
who looks like me

in a field with white
males is going to be hard. And so acknowledge that,
but also get a vision

of where you want to go. So he clearly taught
me, said, do you know where you want to work? And I said, I think I know.

He says, so where is that? I said the Lawrence
Livermore National Labs in Livermore, California.

He says that's very
specific-- good for you. I said, I know because
I visited there, and I thought it was
a great place to work.

OK, you know what it looks like. Picture that in your head. What does this guy look like? What does the
landscape look like?

What time of year is it? What does it smell like? And for me, California
smell-- the air smells sweet

because you have so much
moisture in the air. And the grass was green because,
this time of the year, there's a lot of rain that
happened in the spring--

yeah, in the winter
and now spring. You have beautiful hills
of green, green grass and wildflowers.

I could picture that
because I've seen it. And there I am, walking to the
building where I would work.

And on my trip,
my field visit, I said, where would a
civil engineer work at this laboratory?

They said, here's the
building, Plant Engineering. We take care of
the infrastructure.

And so I had that vision. He says, there you
are, your first day. What's in your hands? I said, I've got my purse.

I've got my mechanical pencil. I have my calculator because
that's what engineers do. We carry that around with us.

And I said, I'm going
to carry my lunch, because I know I'm
going to have student loans I have to pay off. So I've got to watch my money.

He says, all that
is clear to you. Walk in the building, and
sit down at your desk. And you're going to start work.

That's how clear you need to
have a vision of where you're going to have a future foothold
in either a job or a career,

because when things go wrong,
when your health goes down, you have to create
that image in your mind

so that you get through what
you're going through now-- the pitfall, the hold, the
boulder you can't get around.

That vision will help
you get to that point so that you're very clear
of where you want to get.

Now, your vision may
change over time. But that's OK. That's the way things
should be in your life.

You grow, and you change. I'll give you one
of my first bosses. He said, you know
what, Sandra, you

need to learn to talk about
your work with your coworkers. OK, next you need to talk
to me about your work,

I said, OK, I thought
you were observing. You kind of knew
what I was doing. Yes, I'm observing, but I want
you to tell me about your work.

By the way, now you need
to talk to other managers about your work. Oh, and you need to talk
to upper-level people

about your work. I had no idea. But it all had to do with
performance management appraisals.

They need to know who you are,
what you do, short and snappy. Don't talk their
ear off, but they

have to be aware, because at
that point in your career, you're being viewed as how
great a performer you are,

how might you be rewarded with a
bonus, how much raise you might get based on your
communication, your performance

appraisal, written material,
knowledge of what your work is about. And so I had that
as a great learning.

I had no idea. Nobody taught me that. So I'm telling you today. You've got to talk
about your work

with people who have influence
on evaluating your performance.

Last, I'm going to leave
off with thinking about how to take care of yourself.

So you must not overdo things. You've got to take
your days off.

You've got to rest. I'm learning, on the
weekends, I just have to rest.

And I cannot push, push, push
with all these activities that people want me to
be involved with.

I have to say no, because
my body, at my age, I have to give it
time to recuperate.

And so even getting
ready for today, I had a little bit
of morning meetings.

But I deliberately
went to bed early because I needed to be energetic
and on my best showing of what

I can do in this forum today. And so planning ahead
for these things

does you a world of difference. Eating right, drinking enough
water-- some of these things are basic.

But I'm here to remind you
they're very, very important. You have got to take
care of yourself.

The other illustration
I'll give you and leave with you is, if
you're in an airplane, and the oxygen comes down, and
you're supposed to be getting

your oxygen, don't help others. Help yourself first. Put the oxygen mask on yourself,
then you can help others.

Otherwise, you're going
to pass out because you didn't put your oxygen mask on. So that's another
illustration for me.

It's important for you
to take care of yourself. If you don't, you can't
help take care of others.

You have to be good at
taking care of yourself. And I guess I will
leave off right there.

And I'm hoping we have a
whole variety of questions. So thank you, and I look
forward to your questions.

SPEAKER: Sandra, thank
you so much for that. We do have a variety
of questions.

I was listening so intently
on what you were saying, and I would come
up with a question

myself in the middle of
when you were talking. And then you would answer
it right after that. But there's so many
things that would

be so helpful to just
take another look at.

A couple of things that
you said that really stuck with me is you mentioned
a mentor you had, Don Coyis.

He helped you with some
strategic planning, it sounded like, for
your overall career.

And you mentioned your
manager and how he said, you need to talk
more about your work and around the organization,
be snappy, but do it.

Did you feel supported by-- you have some
mentors, but did you feel supported by
your male colleagues

in your efforts to improve
minority representation in STEM while you were going
through your career?

You've mentioned a
couple of mentors, but did you also
have that support?

SANDRA BEGAY: I did. I'll just say, I'm lucky. I don't think
everybody is lucky.

But aside from that--
that's important, but what you need
to really shore up for yourself is to have
personal mentors that

are not work-related. So my mom was my first mentor. As a working mother,
she went back

for her Bachelor of Science
